Functions module¶

functions.A_matrix(phi: float) → ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]¶

Computes the 2D rotation matrix for a given angle.

The rotation matrix is used to rotate a vector in 2D space by an angle phi (in radians).

Parameters:

(float) (phi) -- Angle of rotation in radians.

Returns:

A 2x2 rotation matrix.

Return type:

A (NDArray)

functions.as_column_property(name)¶

Creates a property that ensures the assigned value is always stored as a column numpy array.

This function converts the assigned value to a column numpy array of shape (n, 1), regardless of whether the input is a list, a 1D numpy array, or a 2D numpy array.

Parameters:

(str) (name) -- The name of the property to define. The actual value is stored in a private attribute named with an underscore prefix.

Returns:

A property object that enforces column-vector format on assignment.

Return type:

property

functions.colvect(*args)¶

Create a column vector from the provided values.

Parameters:

*args (float or int) -- A variable number of arguments or a list representing the elements of the column vector. If a list is provided, it will be used to create the column vector.

Returns:

A column vector with shape (n, 1), where n is the number of provided elements.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

Examples

>>> colvect(1, 2, 3)
array([[1],
       [2],
       [3]])

>>> colvect([4, 5, 6])
array([[4],
       [5],
       [6]])
functions.friction_A(mu_s: float, mu_d: float, v_s: float, p: float, k_t: float, v: float, fN: float) → float¶

Calculate the friction force based on the Anderson et al. model.

This function computes the friction force using a model where the viscous friction is not included. The formula takes into account the transition from static to dynamic friction, with an exponential decay controlled by the slip velocity v relative to a reference slip velocity v_s.

Parameters:

  • (float) (fN) -- The coefficient of static friction. Represents the friction when the body is at rest.

  • (float) -- The coefficient of dynamic friction. Represents the friction when the body is in motion.

  • (float) -- The reference slip velocity where the transition between static and dynamic friction occurs.

  • (float) -- The exponent parameter that controls the rate of exponential decay in the friction model.

  • (float) -- A parameter that scales the hyperbolic tangent function, affecting how sharply the friction changes with velocity.

  • (float) -- The relative slip velocity between the contacting surfaces.

  • (float) -- The normal force, representing the force perpendicular to the contact surface.

Returns:

The computed friction force.

Return type:

friction_force (float)

Note

Typical values for the v_s, p and k_t are: 0.001 (m/s), 2 and 10 respectively.

functions.friction_B(mu_s: float, mu_d: float, mu_v: float, v_t: float, fnt: float, v: float, fN: float) → float¶

Calculate the friction force based on the Brown-McPhee model.

This function computes the friction force using the Brown-McPhee model, which includes the effects of viscous friction. The formula accounts for both the transition from static to dynamic friction as well as the influence of relative slip velocity and normal force.

Parameters:

  • (float) (fN) -- The coefficient of static friction. Represents the friction when the body is at rest.

  • (float) -- The coefficient of dynamic friction. Represents the friction when the body is in motion.

  • (float) -- The coefficient of viscous friction, representing the friction that is proportional to velocity.

  • (float) -- A reference velocity that scales the transition between static and dynamic friction.

  • (float) -- A threshold normal force that affects the transition between different friction regimes.

  • (float) -- The relative slip velocity between the contacting surfaces.

  • (float) -- The normal force, representing the force perpendicular to the contact surface.

Returns:

The computed friction force.

Return type:

friction_force (float)

functions.functData(Ci, Functs)¶
functions.get_globals()¶

Retrieve the global variables of the calling module.

This method uses the inspect module to access the stack and fetch the global variables from the caller's context.

Returns:

A dictionary of the caller's global variables.

Return type:

dict

functions.group_classes()¶

Looping through all the global variables this method returns a dictionary, in which, all the defined instances are contained.

Returns:

A dictionary where each key is a class name (string) and the corresponding value is a list of instances of that class type.

Return type:

dict

functions.my_r_Point(r: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], s_P_local: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], A: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], s_P: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]] = None) → ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]¶

Computes the coordinates of point P relative to a global reference frame.

This function calculates the global position of a point P that belongs to a body, using the fundamental principles of kinematics. If the position of point P relative to the local reference frame is already known in global coordinates as the vector s_P, the global position can be determined by simply adding s_P to the position vector r. If the position of point P is known only relative to the local reference frame (i.e., as s_P_local, and s_P is not directly known), it must first be transformed into global coordinates using the rotation matrix A, and then added to the vector r.

Parameters:

  • (NDArray) (A) -- A vector representing the position of the body's reference point (e.g., the origin of the local reference frame) in the global coordinate system. This defines where the local reference frame is situated in global coordinates.

  • (NDArray) -- A vector representing the position of point P relative to the body's reference point, expressed in the local reference frame. This defines the position of P within the local frame before any transformation.

  • (NDArray) -- The rotation matrix that transforms vectors from the local reference frame to the global reference frame. It is used to express s_P_local in global coordinates.

  • (NDArray (s_P) -- A vector representing the position of point P, already expressed in the global reference frame. If this is provided, it is used directly to compute the global position of P without the need for transformation.

  • optional) -- A vector representing the position of point P, already expressed in the global reference frame. If this is provided, it is used directly to compute the global position of P without the need for transformation.

Returns:

A vector representing the global coordinates of point P with respect to the global reference frame.

Return type:

r_P (NDArray)

functions.my_r_Point_d(r_d: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], s_P_local: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], A: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], phi_d: float, s_P: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]] = None) → ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]¶

Calculate the velocity of a point belonging to a rigid body using kinematic relations.

Given a rigid body in motion, the velocity of a point P on the body can be expressed as the sum of the velocity of a reference point (which could be the origin of the body’s local reference frame or its center of mass) and the velocity due to the rotational motion of the body around this reference point. The latter term is calculated as the cross product of the body's angular velocity vector and the relative position vector of point P with respect to the reference point.

This relationship is given by the equation:

v_P = v_O + ω × r_{P/O}

where: - v_P: velocity of point P in global coordinates - v_O: velocity of the reference point O in global coordinates - ω: angular velocity of the body (expressed in radians per second) - r_{P/O}: position vector of P relative to O in global coordinates.

Parameters:

  • (NDArray) (A) -- The velocity vector of the reference point (e.g., the center of mass or the origin of the local reference frame) of the body, expressed in global coordinates.

  • (NDArray) -- A vector representing the position of point P expressed in the local reference frame. This defines the position of P within the local frame.

  • (NDArray) -- The rotation matrix that transforms vectors from the local reference frame to the global reference frame. It is used to express s_P_local in global coordinates.

  • (float) (phi_d) -- The angular velocity of the body around the axis of rotation, expressed in radians per second.

  • (NDArray (s_P) -- A vector representing the position of point P in global coordinates. If this is provided, the function uses this value directly to compute the velocity of P. If None, s_P will be calculated using the rotation matrix A and the local position s_P_local.

  • optional) -- A vector representing the position of point P in global coordinates. If this is provided, the function uses this value directly to compute the velocity of P. If None, s_P will be calculated using the rotation matrix A and the local position s_P_local.

Returns:

The velocity vector of point P, expressed in global coordinates.

Return type:

r_P_d (NDArray)

functions.my_r_Point_dd(r_dd: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], s_P_local: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], A: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], phi_d: float, phi_dd: float, s_P: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]] = None) → ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]¶

Calculate the acceleration of a point belonging to a rigid body using kinematic relations.

Given a rigid body in motion, the acceleration of a point P on the body can be expressed as a function of the acceleration of a reference point (e.g., the origin of the local reference frame or center of mass) of the body, the angular acceleration of the body, and the relative position of point P with respect to the reference point.

The acceleration is computed using the following equation:

a_P = a_O + α × r_{P/O} + ω × (ω × r_{P/O})

where: - a_P: acceleration of point P in global coordinates - a_O: acceleration of the reference point O in global coordinates - α: angular acceleration of the body - r_{P/O}: position vector of P relative to O, expressed in global coordinates.

Parameters:

  • (NDArray) (A) -- The acceleration vector of the reference point (e.g., the center of mass or the local reference frame's origin) of the body, expressed in global coordinates.

  • (NDArray) -- The position vector of point P relative to the reference point, expressed in the local reference frame. This defines the position of P within the local frame.

  • (NDArray) -- The rotation matrix that transforms vectors from the local reference frame to the global reference frame. It is used to express s_P_local in global coordinates.

  • (float) (phi_dd) -- The angular velocity of the body around the axis of rotation, expressed in radians per second.

  • (float) -- The angular acceleration of the body around the axis of rotation, expressed in radians per second squared.

  • (NDArray (s_P) -- The position vector of point P relative to the reference point, expressed in global coordinates. If not provided, it will be computed from the local reference frame.

  • optional) -- The position vector of point P relative to the reference point, expressed in global coordinates. If not provided, it will be computed from the local reference frame.

Returns:

The acceleration vector of point P, expressed in global coordinates.

Return type:

r_P_dd (NDArray)

functions.pp_s(d: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], k: float, L0: float)¶

Calculate the force generated by a spring element in a planar multibody system.

Parameters:

  • (ndarray) (d) -- Displacement vector between two points in the system. It represents the relative position of the endpoints of the spring.

  • (float) (L0) -- Stiffness coefficient of the spring, representing its resistance to deformation (N/m).

  • (float) -- Rest length of the spring when no force is applied (m).

Returns:

Force vector applied by the spring element, oriented along the direction of displacement and with a magnitude proportional to the deformation from the rest length (N).

Return type:

f_s (ndarray)

functions.pp_sd(d: ndarray, d_d: ndarray, k: float, L0: float, dc: float) → ndarray¶

Calculate the force generated by a spring-damper element in a planar multibody system.

Parameters:

  • (ndarray) (d_d) -- Displacement vector between two points in the system. It represents the relative position of the endpoints of the element.

  • (ndarray) -- Relative velocity vector between the two points, representing the rate of change of the displacement (m/s).

  • (float) (dc) -- Stiffness coefficient of the spring (N/m).

  • (float) -- Rest length of the spring when no force is applied (m).

  • (float) -- Damping coefficient, representing the resistance to relative velocity between the two points (Ns/m).

Returns:

Force vector applied by the spring-damper element, combining both spring force and damping force (N).

Return type:

f_sd (ndarray)

functions.pp_sda(d: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], d_d: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], k: float, L0: float, dc: float, fa: float) → ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]¶

Calculate the force generated by a spring-damper-actuator element in a planar multibody system.

Parameters:

  • (ndarray) (d_d) -- Displacement vector between two points in the system. It represents the relative position of the endpoints of the element.

  • (ndarray) -- Relative velocity vector between the two points, representing the rate of change of the displacement (m/s).

  • (float) (fa) -- Stiffness coefficient of the spring (N/m).

  • (float) -- Rest length of the spring when no force is applied (m).

  • (float) -- Damping coefficient, representing the resistance to relative velocity between the two points (Ns/m).

  • (float) -- Actuator force, representing an externally applied force that modifies the behavior of the spring-damper system (N).

Returns:

Force vector applied by the spring-damper-actuator element, combining spring force, damping force, and actuator force (N).

Return type:

f_sda (ndarray)

functions.r_Point(r: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], s_P: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]) → ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]¶

Computes the coordinates of point P relative to a global reference frame.

This function calculates the global position of a point P that belongs to a body, using the fundamental principles of kinematics. The global position r_P is determined by adding the position vector r (representing the location of the local reference frame relative to the global reference frame) to the global position vector s_P (representing the position of point P relative to the body's reference point, defined in the local coordinate system).

Parameters:

  • r (NDArray) -- A vector representing the position of the body's reference point in the global coordinate system.

  • s_P (NDArray) -- A vector representing the position of point P relative to the body's reference point, defined in the local coordinate system.

Returns:

r_P -- A vector representing the global coordinates of point P in the global reference frame.

Return type:

NDArray

functions.r_Point_d(r_d: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], s_P: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], phi_d: float) → ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]¶

Calculate the velocity of a point belonging to a rigid body using kinematic relations.

Given a rigid body in motion, the velocity of a point P on the body can be expressed as the sum of the velocity of a reference point (which could be the origin of the body’s local reference frame or its center of mass) and the velocity due to the rotational motion of the body around this reference point. The latter term is calculated as the cross product of the body's angular velocity vector and the relative position vector of point P with respect to the reference point.

This relationship is given by the equation:

v_P = v_O + ω × r_{P/O}

where: - v_P: velocity of point P in global coordinates - v_O: velocity of the reference point O in global coordinates - ω: angular velocity of the body (expressed in radians per second) - r_{P/O}: position vector of P relative to O, expressed in

the local reference frame and transformed to global coordinates.

Parameters:

  • (NDArray) (s_P) -- The velocity vector of the reference point of the body, expressed in global coordinates. This could be the velocity of the origin of the body’s local reference frame or its center of mass.

  • (NDArray) -- The position vector of point P, expressed in the global reference frame. This represents the coordinates of point P in global terms.

  • (float) (phi_d) -- The angular velocity of the body around the axis of rotation, expressed in radians per second.

Returns:

The velocity vector of point P, expressed in global coordinates.

Return type:

r_P_d (NDArray)

functions.r_Point_dd(r_dd: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], s_P_local: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], A: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], phi_d: float, phi_dd: float) → ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]¶

Calculate the acceleration of a point belonging to a rigid body using kinematic relations.

Given a rigid body in motion, the acceleration of a point P on the body can be expressed as a function of the acceleration of a reference point (e.g., the origin or center of mass) of the body, the angular acceleration of the body, and the relative position of point P with respect to the reference point.

The acceleration is computed using the following equation:

a_P = a_O + α × r_{P/O} + ω × (ω × r_{P/O})

where: - a_P: acceleration of point P in global coordinates - a_O: acceleration of the reference point O in global coordinates - α: angular acceleration of the body - r_{P/O}: position vector of P relative to O, initially expressed

in the local reference frame and transformed to global coordinates.

Parameters:

  • r_dd (NDArray) -- The acceleration vector of the reference point (e.g., the center of mass) of the body, expressed in global coordinates.

  • s_P_local (NDArray) -- The position vector of point P relative to the reference point, expressed in the local reference frame. This defines the position of P within the local frame.

  • A (NDArray) -- The rotation matrix that transforms vectors from the local reference frame to the global reference frame. It is used to express s_P_local in global coordinates.

  • phi_d (float) -- The angular velocity of the body around the axis of rotation, expressed in radians per second.

  • phi_dd (float) -- The angular acceleration of the body around the axis of rotation, expressed in radians per second squared.

Returns:

r_P_dd -- The acceleration vector of point P, expressed in global coordinates.

Return type:

NDArray

functions.r_s(theta: float, k: float, theta0: float)¶

Calculate the torque generated by a torsional spring.

The torque is generated by a torsional spring with stiffness k and a rest angle theta0. It is proportional to the angular displacement from the rest angle.

Parameters:

  • (float) (theta0) -- Current angle (radians) of the torsional spring.

  • (float) -- Stiffness of the torsional spring (Nm/rad).

  • (float) -- Rest angle of the torsional spring (radians).

Returns:

The torque T_s generated by the torsional spring (Nm).

Return type:

T_s (float)

functions.r_sd(theta: float, theta_d: float, k: float, theta0: float, dc: float)¶

Calculate the torque generated by a torsional spring and a torsional damper.

The total torque is generated by a torsional spring with stiffness k and rest angle theta0, along with a torsional damper with damping constant dc that resists angular velocity.

Parameters:

  • (float) (dc) -- Current angle (radians) of the system.

  • (float) -- Angular velocity (radians/second).

  • (float) -- Stiffness of the torsional spring (Nm/rad).

  • (float) -- Rest angle of the torsional spring (radians).

  • (float) -- Damping coefficient of the torsional damper (Nm·s/rad).

Returns:

The torque T_sd generated by the combined spring and damper (Nm).

Return type:

T_sd (float)

functions.r_sda(theta: float, theta_d: float, k: float, theta0: float, dc: float, Ta: float)¶

Calculate the torque generated by a torsional actuator system.

The total torque is generated by a system consisting of a torsional spring with stiffness k and rest angle theta0, a torsional damper with damping constant dc, and an actuator that provides a constant torque Ta.

Parameters:

  • (float) (Ta) -- Current angle (radians) of the system.

  • (float) -- Angular velocity (radians/second).

  • (float) -- Stiffness of the torsional spring (Nm/rad).

  • (float) -- Rest angle of the torsional spring (radians).

  • (float) -- Damping coefficient of the torsional damper (Nm·s/rad).

  • (float) -- Constant torque provided by the actuator (Nm).

Returns:

The torque T_sda generated by the combined spring, damper, and actuator (Nm).

Return type:

T_sda (float)

functions.rowvect(*args)¶

Create a row vector from the provided values.

Parameters:

*args (float or int) -- A variable number of arguments or a list representing the elements of the row vector. If a list is provided, it will be used to create the row vector.

Returns:

A row vector with shape (1, n), where n is the number of provided elements.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

Examples

>>> rowvect(1, 2, 3)
array([[1, 2, 3]])

>>> rowvect([4, 5, 6])
array([[4, 5, 6]])
functions.s_rot(vect: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]) → ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]¶

Computes a 90-degree counterclockwise rotation of a 2D vector.

Given a 2D vector vect represented as a NumPy array, returns a new vector that is rotated 90 degrees counterclockwise.

Parameters:

(ndarray) (vect) -- A NumPy array with two elements representing the vector to be rotated.

Returns:

A NumPy array containing the rotated vector.

Return type:

s_r (ndarray)

(NDArray) (u) -- Vector along which create the unit vector.

Returns:

Unit vector required.

Return type:

u_hat (NDArray)

functions.validate_shape(vec: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]])¶

Check if the input vector is a column vector with 2 rows.

Parameters:

(np.ndarray) (vec) -- The input vector to be checked.

Raises:

ValueError -- if the input is not a column vector with 2 rows.:
